Novy 20-97 12:19 the business center
Minnesota
Republican Party of Minnesota
480 Cedar Street, Suite 560 Saint Paul, Minnesota 55101
Bill Cooper State Chairman
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE November 20, 1997
(612) 222-0022 (612) 224-4122 (fax) TO: Media Aff, Settlement, Paul Lucas, Scott Fisher FROM: Nicole DAWSON CONTACT: Tony Sutton 612-222-0022
HUMPHREY TOBACCO SUIT HELPS HIM BUT HURTS KIDS, TAXPAYERS Lawsuit risks all, But Lawyer Fees for his Campaign Contributors Likely to Top $1 billion
ST. PAUL., MN-Attorney General Hubert "Skip" Humphrey is selling out children and taxpayers in order to pursue a risky tobacco lawsuit which largely benefits him and his trial lawyer supporters. Republican Party Chairman Bill Cooper said today.
"Minnesota children and taxpayers are the big winners if Minnesota takes part in a national tobacco settlement. Under that settlement, the state would have millions of new dollars to spend on programs that reduce teen smoking and improve public health," Cooper said. "Instead, Mr. Humphrey is gambling with the health of teenagers in order to grandstand in the courts and to get a huge payoff for the trial lawyers who contribute to his campaign."
Cooper noted that Humphrey signed a contract to give the law firm of Robins, Kaplan, Miller and Ciresi 25%, plus expenses, of any tobacco deal. Estimates are that Minnesota would gain $4-5 billion under a national settlement. Therefore, the Ciresi law firm stands to gain at least $1 billion under the Humphrey contract. Each partner in the firm would earn an average of $9 million. "Why would the Attorney General's office with some 300 lawyers on staff paid for with taxpayer dollars need to hire an outside law firm and pay them over a billion dollars?" wondered Cooper.
Minnesota is only one of four states that plan to award outside legal counsel 25% or more of any tobacco settlement, reports the National Association of Attorney's General. A Florida judge recently ruled that a similar 25% contract in that state was "unconscionable".
According to state campaign finance records, Ciresi and seven others at his law firm (including former Humphrey Chief of Staff Richard Allyn) contributed the maximum allowable amount of $500 each on New Year's Eve in 1996 to Humphrey. In one night, the members of the firm gave $4000 to help launch Humphrey's gubernatorial campaign. Trial lawyers in Minnesota have been major financial supporters of the DFL and DFL candidates.
1997 records are not yet available. But Cooper challenged Humphrey and the Ciresi firm to disclose now, the amount firm members contributed to Humphrey's campaign coffers this year.
Regardless, Cooper urges the Attorney General to do the right thing and cancel this outrageous giveaway to lawyers by abandoning this risky lawsuit now. "Children and taxpayers should not have their health and money jeopardized just because Skip Humphrey seeks publicity to run for higher political office."
1 2073112187
Prepared and paid for by the Republican Party of Minnesota, 480 Cedar Street, Suile 560, St. Paul MN 55101, Bill Couper. Chairman.
